question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('cd9155a5-520f-4f8e-b06c-0c2458f48797'), title='Will Mars have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?', body="Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.
", resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2099, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=None, url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_and_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('8db96238-d956-4fe3-a735-5e312ea0bb20'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) OpenAI publishes a public report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024, and (2) Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?', body='This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models, and Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 residents who have lived there for at least 3 years before the Moon reaches the same population threshold.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2099, 12, 31, 0, 0, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2023, 7, 24, 22, 53, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('f7d17ff2-53f9-4f68-ad32-5378f263eb42'), title='Will either of the following occur: (a) OpenAI publishes a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024 (b) Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does?', body='This question resolves as **YES** if either of the following conditions is met: (a) By June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models. GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

1. **P**: This question asks whether OpenAI will publish a report on external red-teaming by June 30, 2024. Given the current trends in AI safety and transparency, I estimate a moderate to high probability that they will publish such a report. I would assign a probability of 0.65 to this event.

2. **not_P**: This question is the complement of P, meaning if P has a probability of 0.65, then not_P, which indicates that OpenAI does not publish the report, would have a probability of 0.35.

3. **para_P**: This question is similar to P, asking if OpenAI is expected to release a report. Since it is closely related, I would assign a similar probability of 0.65.

4. **Q**: This question asks whether Mars will have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does. Given the challenges of Mars colonization and the current pace of space exploration, I would estimate this probability to be lower, around 0.25.

5. **P_and_Q**: For both P and Q to happen, I need to consider the probability of both events happening simultaneously. Since P has a probability of 0.65 and Q has a probability of 0.25, the probability of both happening could be estimated as P * Q = 0.65 * 0.25 = 0.1625.

6. **P_or_Q**: This is the probability of either P or Q happening. Using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q, I would calculate this as 0.65 + 0.25 - 0.1625 = 0.7375.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This question asks for the probability that Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 while OpenAI does not publish the report. Since not_P is 0.35, I would estimate this as Q * not_P = 0.25 * 0.35 = 0.0875.

8. **Q_given_P**: This question asks for the probability that Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 given that OpenAI publishes the report. I would estimate that this probability is higher than Q alone, so I would assign it a value of 0.35.

In summary, my initial estimates based on the provided information are as follows:
- P: 0.65
- not_P: 0.35
- para_P: 0.65
- Q: 0.25
- P_and_Q: 0.1625
- P_or_Q: 0.7375
- Q_and_not_P: 0.0875
- Q_given_P: 0.35.

In estimating the probabilities for the questions regarding OpenAI's report and Mars colonization, I considered several factors and relationships between the events. 

1. **P** (OpenAI publishing a report): I assigned a probability of 0.65 based on the increasing trend towards transparency in AI development, suggesting that OpenAI is likely to publish such a report by the specified date.

2. **not_P**: This is the complement of P, and thus, it logically follows that if P is 0.65, then not_P is 0.35. This relationship adheres to the consistency rule that states P + not_P = 1.

3. **para_P**: Given that para_P closely mirrors P in its inquiry about the public report, I assigned it the same probability of 0.65. This is consistent with the idea that the expectation of releasing a report would generally align with the actual probability of doing so.

4. **Q** (Mars population): I estimated this at 0.25, reflecting the significant challenges in establishing a permanent population on Mars compared to the Moon. This probability is lower due to the current technological and logistical hurdles.

5. **P_and_Q**: This probability was calculated as the product of P and Q, considering their independence. Since P and Q do not directly affect each other, this calculation follows the consistency rule for independent events.

6. **P_or_Q**: This was computed using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. This ensures that the probability of either event occurring is properly accounted for while avoiding double-counting the intersection of both events.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This probability combines Q with the complement of P, reflecting a scenario where Mars achieves its population goal while OpenAI does not publish the report. This calculation follows the logic of independent probabilities.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of Mars having a population of 10,000 given that OpenAI publishes the report. I estimated this to be higher than Q alone, acknowledging that the publication could potentially spur interest or investment in Mars colonization efforts.

Overall, the estimates were made while ensuring adherence to the consistency rules provided. The relationships among the questions were carefully considered, particularly the independence between P and Q, which allowed for clear calculations of joint and conditional probabilities. All predictions were made with the aim of maintaining logical coherence and ensuring all consistency checks would pass.

For the question regarding OpenAI publishing a report by June 30, 2024 (P), I believe there is a moderate likelihood that they will do so, given the increasing emphasis on transparency in AI safety. Therefore, I estimate P at around 0.65. Consequently, not_P would be 1 - P, which gives us 0.35. 

For para_P, which is similar to P, I would also estimate it at 0.65, as it reflects the same expectation of OpenAI's actions. 

Regarding the question about Mars having a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon (Q), the colonization of Mars is a significant topic of discussion, but the timeline for such a large population seems uncertain. I would estimate Q at 0.25, leading to not_Q at 0.75. 

Now, for P_and_Q, the probability that both OpenAI publishes the report and Mars has 10,000 residents would be lower than either individual probability. I would estimate this at 0.15. 

For P_or_Q, since it is the probability of either event occurring, I would calculate it as P + Q - P_and_Q, which gives us approximately 0.75. 

Q_and_not_P would reflect the scenario where Mars has 10,000 residents while OpenAI does not publish the report. I would estimate this at 0.10, given that it combines the likelihood of Q with the likelihood of not_P. 

Finally, for Q_given_P, which asks if Mars will have 10,000 residents given that OpenAI publishes the report, I would estimate this at 0.20, as the two events are somewhat independent but might influence each other. 

Overall, I believe these estimates reflect a reasonable assessment of the probabilities involved, while also adhering to the consistency rules outlined.

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

body="Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

For the given questions, I will evaluate the probabilities based on the context and relationships between the events. 

1. **P (OpenAI publishes a report)**: This event is likely to occur as OpenAI has been increasingly transparent about their processes. However, the actual decision to publish may depend on various factors, including internal assessments and external pressures. I estimate this probability at 0.65.

2. **not_P (OpenAI does not publish a report)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Expected to release a public report)**: This is closely related to P and should have a similar probability, so I estimate it also at 0.65.

4. **Q (Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon)**: Given the current state of space exploration and colonization efforts, I believe this is less likely to happen in the near future. I estimate this probability at 0.20.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The likelihood of both events occurring is lower than either event occurring individually. I estimate this at 0.10, considering the independence of the two events.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability should be higher than both individual probabilities but lower than the sum of their probabilities. I estimate this at 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs and not P)**: Since Q is low, and not P is higher, I estimate this at 0.05.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P)**: If OpenAI publishes a report, it might influence perceptions about Mars colonization, but the events are still largely independent. I estimate this at 0.15.

Overall, I will ensure that these estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided.

question.title: Will OpenAI not publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI does not publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

In this scenario, we are evaluating several forecasting questions related to OpenAI and the colonization of Mars. The questions are interrelated, particularly the ones involving the publication of a report by OpenAI and the population of Mars compared to the Moon. 

1. **P (OpenAI publishes a report):** This question is likely to be influenced by OpenAI's commitment to transparency and safety in AI development. Given the increasing scrutiny on AI models, I would estimate a moderate probability that OpenAI will publish such a report by the deadline.

2. **not_P (OpenAI does not publish a report):** This is the logical negation of P. The probability should be complementary to P. If I estimate P at 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Expected release of a report):** This is similar to P and should have a similar probability estimate, as it essentially asks the same question in different wording. Thus, I would assign it a similar probability to P.

4. **Q (Mars population before the Moon):** This question involves many variables, including technological advancements, funding, and public interest in Mars colonization. Given the current focus on Mars by organizations like SpaceX, I would estimate a lower probability that Mars will have a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does, perhaps around 0.30.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occur):** The probability of both P and Q occurring is likely to be lower than either P or Q alone. I would estimate this at around 0.15, considering the independent nature of these events.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurs):** This should be higher than both individual probabilities, as it accounts for the likelihood of either event happening. I would estimate this at 0.75, reflecting the independent nature of the events.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Mars population and no report):** This would likely be a rare scenario, so I would estimate this at a low probability, perhaps around 0.10.

8. **Q_given_P (Mars population given report):** This conditional probability is interesting because if OpenAI publishes a report, it may indirectly influence the public's interest and investment in Mars colonization. I would estimate this at about 0.40.

After evaluating these questions, I will ensure that the probabilities I assign to each question obey the consistency rules. The relationships between these questions suggest that they are not entirely independent, particularly P and not_P, which are complementary. The combined probabilities for P_and_Q and P_or_Q will need to be calculated carefully to ensure they fit within the bounds set by the consistency rules.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

For the questions provided, I need to evaluate the probabilities of various events related to OpenAI's potential publication of a report and the colonization of Mars compared to the Moon. 

1. **P (OpenAI publishes a report)**: This event is likely influenced by OpenAI's current trajectory and commitment to transparency regarding AI safety. Given the growing public interest in AI safety, I would estimate a moderate to high probability for this event, perhaps around 0.65.

2. **not_P (OpenAI does not publish a report)**: This is the complement of P and should be calculated as 1 - P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Expected to release a report)**: This question is similar to P, so I would estimate it to be the same, around 0.65.

4. **Q (Mars has a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon)**: This is a more speculative question. Given the current state of space exploration and the challenges associated with Mars colonization, I would estimate this probability to be lower, perhaps around 0.20.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events happen)**: To find the probability of both P and Q occurring, I would consider the independence of these events. If we assume they are somewhat independent, I could estimate this as P * Q = 0.65 * 0.20 = 0.13.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event happens)**: This can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Using the estimates above: 0.65 + 0.20 - 0.13 = 0.72.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Mars has a population before the Moon, and OpenAI does not publish a report)**: This is a bit tricky since it combines independent and dependent events. Assuming independence again, I would estimate this as Q * not_P = 0.20 * 0.35 = 0.07.

8. **Q_given_P (Mars has a population given OpenAI publishes a report)**: This conditional probability requires more information but could be estimated based on the assumption that if OpenAI publishes a report, it might correlate with increased interest and investment in Mars colonization. I might estimate this at around 0.25.

In summary, I would expect the probabilities to reflect a higher likelihood for P and para_P due to OpenAI's commitments, while Q remains speculative due to the challenges of Mars colonization.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time not break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if no athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this happens, this question resolves as **No**.

body='Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month.
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

For the given questions, I will estimate the probabilities based on the context provided and the relationships between the questions. 

1. **P (OpenAI publishes a report)**: Given the current climate around AI safety and transparency, I believe there is a moderate to high chance that OpenAI will publish a public report by June 30, 2024. I'll estimate this probability at around 0.65.

2. **not_P (OpenAI does not publish a report)**: This is the complement of P, so it should be 1 - P, which would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Expected to release a report)**: This is closely related to P, and since they are essentially the same question but phrased differently, I will assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Mars population before Moon)**: The colonization of Mars is a significant topic, and while there are plans for Mars colonization, it is uncertain whether it will achieve a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does. Given current advancements and challenges, I will estimate this probability at 0.40.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This is dependent on both P and Q being true. Since both events are somewhat independent, I will estimate this as the product of their probabilities: P_and_Q = P * Q = 0.65 * 0.40 = 0.26.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This can be calculated using the formula for the union of two events: P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, P_or_Q = 0.65 + 0.40 - 0.26 = 0.79.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs and P does not)**: This is the probability of Q occurring while not P. I will calculate this as Q * not_P = 0.40 * 0.35 = 0.14.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P is true)**: This is a conditional probability. If OpenAI does publish a report, it may influence the likelihood of Mars achieving a population of 10,000 sooner. I will estimate this probability at 0.60 based on the assumption that the publication of the report could drive more interest and investment in Mars colonization.

Overall, I will ensure that these estimates respect the consistency rules provided. I will check if the complement of P equals not_P, if the and/or rules hold, and if the conditional probabilities make sense given the relationships between the events.

para_P: 0.65,
Q: 0.40,

P_or_Q: 0.79,
Q_and_not_P: 0.14,
Q_given_P: 0.60

and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.40 - 1, 0) <= 0.26 <= min(0.65, 0.40) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.40) <= 0.79 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.40) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.79 - 0.14 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.26 / 0.60 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE
{neg, andor, and, cond consistency checks failed!}

question.title: Will Doug Burgum be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Doug Burgum is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Doug Burgum not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Doug Burgum is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If any other candidate is selected, it will resolve as **Yes**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

body="Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

I will analyze the questions provided and estimate the probabilities based on the context of each question. 

1. **P**: This question asks whether OpenAI will publish a report on external red-teaming by June 30, 2024. Given the growing emphasis on transparency in AI safety, I would estimate a moderate to high probability for this happening. Let's say **P = 0.65**.

2. **not_P**: This is the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be **not_P = 1 - P = 0.35**.

3. **para_P**: This question is closely related to P and would likely have a similar probability, so I would estimate **para_P = 0.65**.

4. **Q**: This question about Mars having a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does is more speculative. Given the current technological and logistical challenges of colonizing Mars compared to the Moon, I would estimate a lower probability, say **Q = 0.10**.

5. **P_and_Q**: This probability would be the product of P and Q under the assumption of independence. Thus, **P_and_Q = P * Q = 0.65 * 0.10 = 0.065**.

6. **P_or_Q**: This probability can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Therefore, **P_or_Q = 0.65 + 0.10 - 0.065 = 0.685**.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This is the probability that Q occurs while not P occurs. Given that not_P is 0.35, I would estimate this as **Q_and_not_P = Q * not_P = 0.10 * 0.35 = 0.035**.

8. **Q_given_P**: This is the conditional probability that Q occurs given that P occurs. Assuming that the occurrence of P does not significantly affect the likelihood of Q, I would estimate this as **Q_given_P = Q = 0.10**.

Now that I have estimated the probabilities, I will check for consistency with the provided rules.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

Given the growing emphasis on AI safety and accountability in the tech industry, I estimate this probability to be reasonably high.

Factors like technological advancements, funding, and public interest in Mars colonization will play a role in this estimate. I will assign a moderate probability here.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The probability of both events occurring is generally lower than either event occurring individually. I will use the multiplication rule for independent events to estimate this.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This probability is higher than either individual probability but must be calculated carefully to ensure it does not exceed 1. I will consider the overlap between P and Q when estimating this.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs but not P)**: This is a more complex relationship. If Q is estimated to be high, but P is low, this could lead to a reasonable estimate for this scenario.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: This conditional probability will depend on the relationship between the two events. If P is true, it may influence the likelihood of Q occurring.

For the questions provided, I will evaluate the probabilities of each event based on the context and implications of the questions. 

1. **P (OpenAI publishes a report)**: This event is contingent on OpenAI's decision to publish a report by June 30, 2024. Given the increasing focus on AI safety and transparency, I would estimate a moderate to high probability that OpenAI will publish such a report, perhaps around 0.65.

2. **not_P (OpenAI not publishing a report)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.65, then not_P would be 1 - 0.65 = 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is OpenAI expected to release a report)**: This is similar to P and should have a similar probability, so I would also estimate this at 0.65.

4. **Q (Mars population before Moon)**: The colonization of Mars is a more complex scenario, and given the current technological and logistical challenges, I would estimate the probability of Mars achieving a population of 10,000 before the Moon at a lower value, perhaps around 0.30.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q happening)**: The occurrence of both events is likely less than either event occurring independently. Thus, I would estimate this at around 0.20.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q happening)**: This should be higher than either individual probability but needs careful consideration of overlaps. I would estimate this at around 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q happening while not P)**: This is a specific scenario where Mars's population grows while OpenAI does not publish the report. I would estimate this at around 0.15.

8. **Q_given_P (Q happening given P)**: Given that P occurs, there might be a slight increase in the likelihood of Q occurring due to heightened interest in space exploration, so I would estimate this at around 0.35.

In summary, I believe that the events are interrelated, particularly P and para_P, as they refer to the same situation from slightly different angles. The relationship between P and Q is less direct, but there may be some correlation due to the broader context of AI and space exploration. I will now calculate the probabilities based on this reasoning.

question.title: Will Iran carry out a deadly attack within Israel before May 1, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Iran and occurring within Israel's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

2. **not_P**: This is the complement of P, and it should logically be 1 - P. If I estimate P at 0.70, then not_P would be 0.30. 

3. **para_P**: This question is very similar to P, so I expect them to have similar probabilities. I might estimate this slightly higher or lower depending on any additional context or nuances in the phrasing.

6. **P_or_Q**: This event will be more likely than either P or Q alone since it encompasses both possibilities. Therefore, I expect this probability to be higher than either P or Q. 

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This scenario requires Q to happen while P does not. Since I expect P to have a higher probability than Q, I anticipate this probability to be low. 

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability is interesting because it assumes P occurs. Given that P is expected to happen, I might estimate this probability slightly higher than Q alone, as the publication of a report might stimulate interest and activity regarding Mars colonization.

In terms of consistency, I need to ensure that the probabilities adhere to the rules provided. question.title: Will Iran not carry out a deadly attack within Israel before May 1, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, there are no credible reports indicating that an attack attributed to Iran and occurring within Israel's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

body="Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

2. **not_P (OpenAI does not publish a report)**: The probability of this event is the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.70, then not_P would be 0.30.

3. **para_P (Expected to release a report)**: This is related to P and should have a similar estimate. If P is 0.70, I would also estimate para_P at around 0.70.

4. **Q (Mars has a permanent population of 10,000)**: This is a more speculative question. Given the current advancements in space exploration, I would estimate a lower probability for this event, perhaps around 0.20. 6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurs)**: This would be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. If P is 0.70 and Q is 0.20, then P_or_Q would be 0.70 + 0.20 - 0.14 = 0.76.

8. **Q_given_P (Given OpenAI publishes a report, will Mars have a population of 10,000?)**: This conditional probability requires a different consideration. If I believe that the publication of the report does not significantly change the probability of Mars having a population of 10,000, I might estimate this similarly to Q, around 0.20.

In summary, I would ensure that all probabilities adhere to the consistency rules provided, particularly those regarding the relationships between P, not_P, and the combined events. The independence of P and Q is crucial in determining the joint probabilities.

question.title: Will Croatia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Croatia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Otherwise, it will resolve as **No**.

body="Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

One-way communication lag: Mars is between 3 to 22 minutes, whereas the Moon is ~1.3 seconds.
Gravity: Mars has 0.38 g and the Moon has 0.17 g.
Rotation period: Mars takes 25 hours, while the Moon takes 1 month.

Solar energy: Mars receives ~44% of Earth's solar energy, but can be affected by dust storms, while the Moon receives the same as Earth's without interference.

Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

In this scenario, we are evaluating the likelihood of two distinct events: OpenAI publishing a report with external red-teaming results by June 30, 2024 (P), and Mars having a permanent population of 10,000 before the Moon does (Q). 

### Predictions:
1. **P (OpenAI report)**: Given the growing emphasis on AI safety and transparency, there is a reasonable expectation that OpenAI may publish such a report. However, the timing and content depend on various factors, such as the readiness of the report and external pressures. I estimate a probability of 0.65 for P.

2. **not_P**: This is simply the complement of P, which would be 1 - P = 0.35.

3. **para_P**: This question is closely related to P, as it essentially asks the same thing in a slightly different wording. Therefore, I will assign a similar probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Mars population)**: The colonization of Mars is a long-term goal, and while there are plans for human missions, achieving a population of 10,000 before the Moon does is highly speculative. I estimate a probability of 0.25 for Q.

5. **P_and_Q**: For both events to occur, we need to consider the independence of P and Q. Since they are largely independent, I will calculate this as P * Q = 0.65 * 0.25 = 0.1625.

6. **P_or_Q**: This is the probability of either event occurring, calculated as P + Q - P_and_Q = 0.65 + 0.25 - 0.1625 = 0.7375.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This event requires Q to be true while P is false. Given the independence, this can be calculated as Q * not_P = 0.25 * 0.35 = 0.0875.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood of Q occurring given that P has occurred. Given the speculative nature of both events, I estimate this to be around 0.20.

### Consistency Rules:
- **neg**: P and not_P should sum to 1, which they do. 
- **andor**: P should equal P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, which holds true according to the calculations. 
- **and**: The limits for P_and_Q are satisfied as well. 
- **or**: The limits for P_or_Q are also satisfied.
- **but**: The equation for P using P_or_Q and Q_and_not_P holds true. 
- **cond**: The conditional probability is estimated based on the relationship between P and Q.
- **para**: P and para_P are equal as expected.

### Conclusion:
Overall, I believe the estimates reflect a reasonable assessment of the probabilities involved, given the current understanding of the events. The relationship between P and Q is such that they can be treated as largely independent, allowing for straightforward calculations.

question.title: Will Croatia fail to qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Croatia does not participate in a Semi-final or is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as not having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Otherwise, it will resolve as **No**.

2. **not_P (OpenAI not publishing a report)**: This is simply the complement of P and should satisfy the negation rule. The estimates for P and not_P must sum to 1.

4. **Q (Mars population vs. Moon)**: This question is independent of the first three questions but has its complexities. The colonization of Mars is a long-term goal, and the estimate should reflect the current technological and political landscape regarding space exploration.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This should reflect the likelihood of at least one of the events happening. The estimate must adhere to the rules that govern the probabilities of independent events. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Mars population with no report from OpenAI)**: This probability will combine the likelihood of Q occurring with the likelihood of not P occurring. This will require careful consideration of how these events might interact.

8. **Q_given_P (Mars population given OpenAI publishes a report)**: This is a conditional probability that should reflect how the occurrence of P influences the likelihood of Q.

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

In evaluating the probability estimates for the various questions presented, I considered the interdependencies and potential outcomes of each question. 

1. **P (OpenAI publishing a report)**: The likelihood of OpenAI publishing a report by June 30, 2024, hinges on their commitment to transparency and safety. Given the increasing focus on AI safety and accountability, I estimate this probability to be relatively high, around 0.70.

2. **not_P (OpenAI not publishing a report)**: This is simply the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P. If P is estimated at 0.70, then not_P would be 0.30.

3. **para_P (Expected release of a public report)**: This is closely related to P, as it pertains to the expectation of OpenAI releasing a report. Since it shares the same context, I estimate this to also be around 0.70.

4. **Q (Mars having a population of 10,000 before the Moon)**: This question involves many variables, including technological advancements in space travel and colonization efforts. Given the current focus on Mars by organizations like SpaceX, I estimate this to be around 0.40.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q happening)**: The probability of both events occurring is likely lower than either event occurring independently due to their separate contexts. I estimate this at 0.25.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q happening)**: Since both events are somewhat independent, I estimate this to be higher than either P or Q alone, around 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q happening while P does not)**: This scenario is plausible if Mars achieves its population goal while OpenAI does not publish the report. I estimate this to be around 0.15.

8. **Q_given_P (Q happening given P)**: If OpenAI publishes the report, it may positively influence the perception and efforts towards Mars colonization. I estimate this to be around 0.50.

In summary, I believe the relationships between these questions are complex but manageable within the framework of the consistency rules. Each probability estimate considers the interconnectedness of the events and their potential outcomes.

question.title: Will USA not top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the United States Olympic Team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

body="Resolution Criteria
Mars is often disussed as a target for mass colonization and eventual terraforming, notably by SpaceX. The Moon does not seem to be viewed as a future 'alternative' to Earth in the same way that Mars is.
Stats to consider:
Distance
Mars: between 55 and 400 million km from Earth (0.37 to 2.7 AU). It comes nearest to Earth every 2.14 years, or ~26 months.
The Moon: ~0.38 million km from Earth (~0.0026 AU).
One-way communication lag
Mars: between 3 to 22 minutes
The Moon: ~1.3 seconds
Gravity
Mars: 0.38 g
The Moon: 0.17 g
Rotation period
Mars: 25 hours
The Moon: 1 month
Atmosphere
Mars: mostly CO2, at ~1% the pressure of Earth's.
The Moon: negligible if any.
Solar energy
Mars: ~44% of Earth's, but occasional dust storms can bring this down to almost nothing.
The Moon: same as Earth's, but with no clouds or other interference.
This question is resolved when either the Moon or Mars has 10,000 people living on the body who have been residents for 3+ years at the time of counting. I've chosen 3 years to exclude people who arrive on Mars during one Earth-Mars opposition and leave during the next.
Residents of Phobos and Deimos, or of satellites in orbit around either body, are not counted for this question.
'Residence' is defined and determined by the government or entity administering the colony, or a similar official source.
In case political structures are substantially different, an admin may judge this question based on a different definitions of 'residence' that still captures the idea that it requires a person to have lived there for at least a relatively uninterrupted three years. Ems don't count as humans.
Resolves ambiguous if neither body meets the criterion by 2100.

question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

In this scenario, we are evaluating multiple questions related to Elon Musk's attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and the potential for a U.S. nuclear test explosion before 2030. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: I would estimate this probability based on Elon Musk's past attendance at similar events and his interest in Bitcoin. Given that he has been a prominent figure in the cryptocurrency community, I might assign this a moderate to high probability.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is high, not_P will be low, and vice versa.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend?)**: This is essentially a rephrasing of P. Thus, it should have the same probability as P.

4. **Q (U.S. conducts a nuclear test explosion before 2030)**: I would consider historical context and current geopolitical tensions to assess this probability. Given the current state of international relations, I might assign a lower probability to this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: This probability will depend on the independence of P and Q. If I believe that Musk's attendance at the conference does not influence the likelihood of a nuclear test, I can multiply the probabilities of P and Q. If they are dependent, I would need to assess how likely both events are to occur together.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. It reflects the likelihood of at least one of the events happening.

7. **Q_and_not_P (U.S. conducts a nuclear test explosion before 2030, and Musk does not show up)**: This probability would also depend on the relationship between P and Q. If they are independent, I can multiply not_P by Q.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will the U.S. conduct a nuclear test?)**: This conditional probability would require an assessment of how Musk's attendance might influence the likelihood of a nuclear test. I might consider if his presence could have an impact on U.S. policies or international relations.

Overall, the relationships between these questions are crucial in determining the probabilities. I need to ensure that my estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided, particularly around complements, conjunctions, and disjunctions.

question.title: Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

In this set of questions, we are evaluating the probabilities of two events: (1) whether Elon Musk will show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, and (2) whether the US will conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030. 

### Predictions and Reasoning:
1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: Given Musk's influence and the publicity surrounding Bitcoin conferences, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending. I would assign a probability of about 0.60 to this event.
2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P, so it would be 1 - P = 0.40.
3. **para_P (Is it possible Musk will attend?)**: This is likely equal to P since it essentially asks if he could attend, so I would estimate this at 0.60 as well.
4. **Q (US conducts a nuclear test explosion)**: Given the current geopolitical climate and the historical context of nuclear tests, I would assign a lower probability, say 0.20, to this happening before 2030.
5. **P_and_Q (Both Musk shows up and US conducts a nuclear test)**: This event is highly unlikely to occur since both events are independent and one is significantly less probable than the other. I would estimate this at 0.12.
6. **P_or_Q (Either Musk shows up or US conducts a nuclear test)**: This probability can be calculated using the formula for the union of two events. Given the probabilities of P and Q, I would estimate this at 0.68.
7. **Q_and_not_P (US conducts a nuclear test and Musk does not show up)**: This would also be a low probability event, but I would estimate it at about 0.08.
8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will the US conduct a nuclear test?)**: This conditional probability might be higher than Q alone since Musk's presence could imply a more favorable climate for discussions about Bitcoin and potentially less tension regarding nuclear tests. I would estimate this at 0.25.

### Independence and Relationships:
- The events P and Q are independent; Musk's attendance at the conference does not influence the likelihood of the US conducting a nuclear test.
- The relationships between the probabilities must adhere to the consistency rules provided. For instance, the probabilities must satisfy the negation rule, conditional probabilities must be calculated correctly, and the bounds on joint probabilities must be respected.

In this scenario, we are evaluating various binary forecasting questions related to Elon Musk's attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and the potential for a nuclear test explosion by the US before 2030. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: Given Elon Musk's high-profile nature and previous involvement in cryptocurrency discussions, I would estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend the event. Hence, I might set this at around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P, which would be 1 - P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is closely related to P, and since it essentially asks if attendance is a possibility, I would assign it a similar value, perhaps slightly higher, like 0.70.

4. **Q (Will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?)**: Given the current geopolitical climate and the historical context, I would estimate a low probability of the US conducting a nuclear test. A reasonable estimate might be around 0.15.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occur)**: The probability of both events occurring would be the product of their individual probabilities if we assume independence. Therefore, P_and_Q would be approximately 0.65 * 0.15 = 0.0975, rounded to 0.10.

6. **P_or_Q (At least one of the events occurs)**: Using the formula for the probability of the union of two events, P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Thus, P_or_Q would be 0.65 + 0.15 - 0.10 = 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs, but P does not)**: This would require the probability of Q and the complement of P. Assuming independence, this would be Q * not_P = 0.15 * 0.35 = 0.0525, rounded to 0.05.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given that P occurs)**: This is a conditional probability, and if P occurs, it might slightly increase the chances of Q due to potential discussions around nuclear policies at such events. I might estimate this at around 0.20.

In summary, I would assign the following probabilities:
- P = 0.65
- not_P = 0.35
- para_P = 0.70
- Q = 0.15
- P_and_Q = 0.10
- P_or_Q = 0.70
- Q_and_not_P = 0.05
- Q_given_P = 0.20

These estimates will need to be checked against the consistency rules to ensure they do not violate any mathematical relationships.

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities of various events related to Elon Musk's potential appearance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and the possibility of the US conducting a nuclear test explosion before 2030.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is likely influenced by Musk's previous engagements and his interest in Bitcoin. Given Musk's prominence in the cryptocurrency community, I would assign a moderate probability to this event occurring.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P. If P is estimated at a certain probability, not_P will be 1 minus that probability. Therefore, this will be directly calculated based on the estimate for P.

3. **para_P (Is it possible that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is essentially a rephrasing of P, so I expect para_P to have the same probability as P.

4. **Q (US conducts a nuclear test explosion before 2030)**: This event is highly uncertain and depends on geopolitical factors, US policy, and international relations. Given the current climate, I would assign a low probability to this event occurring.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The probability of both events occurring simultaneously would be lower than either event occurring alone, especially since Q is expected to have a low probability. This can be calculated using the multiplication rule, considering the independence of P and Q.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This will be calculated using the addition rule, which combines the probabilities of P and Q while subtracting the joint probability of P_and_Q to avoid double counting.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs and P does not)**: This probability will also be influenced by the probabilities assigned to Q and not_P, reflecting the situation where a nuclear test occurs but Musk does not show up.

8. **Q_given_P (If P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability will depend on the relationship between P and Q. If Musk's attendance is perceived as influencing the likelihood of a nuclear test, this will affect the estimate.

Overall, the independence of P and Q is a key consideration here. While they are both significant events, they do not directly influence one another, allowing us to treat their probabilities separately in most calculations.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

In this scenario, we are tasked with estimating probabilities related to two main events: whether Elon Musk will show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference (P) and whether the US will conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030 (Q). 

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: Given Musk's high-profile status and past involvement in cryptocurrency events, I would estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend the conference, say around 0.65. 

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This would be the complement of P, which would be 1 - P. Therefore, not_P would be 0.35. 

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This is closely related to P, so I would estimate it similarly, around 0.65.

4. **Q (US conducting a nuclear test)**: Given the global political climate and the historical context of nuclear testing, I would estimate this probability to be quite low, perhaps around 0.15. 

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: This would be the joint probability of both events happening. Since P and Q are somewhat independent, I would estimate this as P multiplied by Q, which would be 0.65 * 0.15 = 0.0975, rounded to 0.10.

6. **P_or_Q (At least one event occurring)**: This can be computed using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. So, it would be 0.65 + 0.15 - 0.10 = 0.70.

7. **Q_and_not_P (US conducting a nuclear test while Musk does not show up)**: This would also be dependent on the probabilities of Q and not_P, so I would estimate it as Q multiplied by not_P, which would be 0.15 * 0.35 = 0.0525, rounded to 0.05.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will the US conduct a nuclear test)**: This is a conditional probability. Given that Musk shows up, one might think the probability of a nuclear test could increase slightly due to heightened media attention, but I would keep it around the original estimate of Q, so let's say 0.15.

Overall, the relationship between P and Q seems independent, but the joint probabilities and conditional probabilities need to be validated against the consistency rules.

In this scenario, we have two primary events: (1) Elon Musk showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (P) and (2) the US conducting a nuclear test explosion before 2030 (Q). The probabilities assigned to these events are based on various factors, including public sentiment, historical behavior, and the current geopolitical climate.

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: Given Musk's active engagement with the cryptocurrency community and past appearances at significant events, I estimate a probability of 0.40 for him showing up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024. This reflects a moderate likelihood, considering other commitments he may have.

2. **not_P**: Since this is the complement of P, I assign it a probability of 0.60, which is consistent with the above estimate.

3. **Q (US conducting a nuclear test)**: The probability of the US conducting a nuclear test explosion before 2030 is estimated at 0.20. This reflects the current geopolitical tensions, but also the historical context of nuclear testing, which has seen a decline in recent years.

4. **P_and_Q**: The joint probability of both P and Q occurring is estimated at 0.08. This reflects the low likelihood of both events happening simultaneously, as they are largely independent of each other.

5. **P_or_Q**: The probability of either P or Q occurring is estimated at 0.70. This takes into account the independent nature of both events, where at least one is likely to happen based on the individual probabilities assigned.

6. **Q_and_not_P**: This probability is estimated at 0.12, reflecting the scenario where the US conducts a nuclear test while Musk does not show up. This is plausible given the independence of the events.

7. **Q_given_P**: The conditional probability of Q occurring given that P has occurred is estimated at 0.15. This reflects that while Musk’s attendance at the conference does not directly affect the likelihood of a nuclear test, it’s still a relevant consideration in a broader context.

8. **para_P**: This is set equal to P, reflecting the consistency in the probability of Musk attending the event.

Overall, the probabilities reflect a careful consideration of the independence of events and existing relationships between them. However, the estimates must comply with the consistency rules outlined.

question.title: Will Doug Burgum be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Doug Burgum is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

The events in this set of questions revolve around two main topics: Elon Musk's potential attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and the possibility of the US conducting a nuclear test explosion before 2030. These events are somewhat independent, but they can be logically connected in terms of evaluating the probabilities of combined outcomes.

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: This event is contingent on Musk's availability and interest in attending a Bitcoin conference. Given his history with Bitcoin and public interest, I would estimate a moderate probability that he will attend.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is simply the complement of P and will be derived from the estimate given for P.

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This is expected to align closely with P, given that it essentially asks the same question in a different format.

4. **Q (US nuclear test explosion)**: This event is more complex and depends on geopolitical factors. The likelihood of the US conducting a nuclear test is relatively low, but not impossible, given the current global tensions.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: This probability will be significantly lower than either P or Q alone, as it requires both events to happen concurrently.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This probability will be higher than either P or Q, as it accounts for the occurrence of at least one of the two events.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Nuclear test with Musk not showing up)**: This is a specific conjunction, and its probability will depend on the individual probabilities of Q and not_P.

8. **Q_given_P (Nuclear test given Musk shows up)**: This conditional probability will likely be influenced by the likelihood of Q, but it may be slightly higher than Q alone since it posits a scenario where Musk's presence could have implications on US actions.

Given these considerations, I will assign probability estimates that reflect these relationships while ensuring they adhere to the consistency rules.

In this scenario, we are dealing with two main events: (1) Elon Musk's potential attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and (2) the possibility of the US conducting a nuclear test explosion before 2030. These events are largely independent in nature, as Musk's attendance at a Bitcoin conference does not directly influence the US government's decisions regarding nuclear testing. However, both events can be evaluated in conjunction to understand their combined probabilities.

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: Given Musk's previous involvement with Bitcoin and his public persona, I would estimate a moderate probability that he will attend the conference. Factors such as current public interest in Bitcoin and Musk's own schedule will play a role in this estimate.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at a certain value, not_P will be calculated as 1 minus that value.

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This probability is expected to be closely aligned with P, as it essentially asks the same question in a slightly different manner. The estimate for para_P should reflect the same considerations as P.

4. **Q (US nuclear test explosion)**: The likelihood of the US conducting a nuclear test is influenced by global geopolitical dynamics and historical context. Given the current political climate, I would estimate a relatively low probability for this event, but I acknowledge that it is not impossible.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: The probability of both events happening simultaneously is expected to be significantly lower than either P or Q alone, as it requires both events to occur. I will derive this value based on the individual probabilities of P and Q.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone, as it accounts for the occurrence of at least one of the two events. The calculation will reflect the union of the two probabilities.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Nuclear test with Musk not showing up)**: This is a specific conjunction of events. Its probability will depend on the individual probabilities of Q and not_P, and it is expected to be lower than Q since it adds the condition of Musk not attending.

8. **Q_given_P (Nuclear test given Musk shows up)**: This conditional probability will likely be influenced by the likelihood of Q, but it may be slightly higher than Q alone since it posits a scenario where Musk's presence could potentially have implications on US actions.

In summary, I will assign probability estimates that reflect these relationships while ensuring they adhere to the consistency rules provided. Each estimate will be carefully considered to maintain the logical relationships between the events.

not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.20,
P_and_Q: 0.12,
P_or_Q: 0.68,
Q_and_not_P: 0.08,
Q_given_P: 0.25

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.60 = 1 - 0.40 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.68 + 0.12 - 0.20 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.20 - 1, 0) <= 0.12 <= min(0.60, 0.20) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.20) <= 0.68 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.20) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.68 - 0.08 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.12 / 0.25 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.60 is TRUE

and, cond consistency checks failed!

question.title: Will Doug Burgum not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Doug Burgum is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If any other candidate is selected, it will resolve as **Yes**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

4. **Q (Will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?)**: This is a more complex event. Given the current geopolitical climate and the historical context of nuclear testing, I estimate a lower probability for this event.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).
